awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Quantitative Train-of-Four monitoring device for quantitatively monitoring neuromuscular blockade in patients undergoing surgery
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a Train-of-Four (TOF) device to provide a method of quantitatively monitoring neuromuscular blockade in patients undergoing surgery. Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) are used extensively to temporarily paralyze patients during surgery. Current methods of measurement have a risk of postoperative residual neuromuscular blockade, where NMBAs remaining in the body after surgery. This postoperative problem can cause muscle weakness and critical respiratory episodes. The current standard Train-of-Four (TOF) monitoring method is qualitative, and anesthesiologists must depend on their eyesight and experience to judge the correct dosing of patients. The proposed device produces a quantitative output, TOF data, to help anesthesiologists gauge how much neuromuscular blockade to administer to each patient and when to reverse its effects. By ensuring complete neuromuscular recovery, the proposed device minimizes respiratory complications and the unpleasant symptom of muscle weakness caused by residual neuromuscular blocking agents in the body post-surgery. The device may prevent unwanted post-operative stress, while potentially saving money for hospitals.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a mechanomyography device that uses medical grade balloons for converting patient response to Train-of-Four (TOF) data. In the device, the use of a peripheral nerve stimulator on the ulnar nerve causes thumb twitches that apply pressure on a balloon. These pressure fluctuations are picked up by a sensor and converted into TOF data to accurately measure the level of neuromuscular blockade in the body by using pressure as the physical analog of muscle numbness and converting it into an electrical signal. The proposed device utilizes mechanomyography, which is thought to be the gold standard and most accurate technology for monitoring neuromuscular blockade, since it directly measures the motion generated as the muscle responds to the ulnar nerve stimulation. There is currently no mechanomyography device on the market to monitor neuromuscular blockade. Furthermore, the proposed device assesses the TOF count and TOF ratio even in positions where the thumb’s movement is restricted; for example, when the hands are tucked beside the body. These types of surgical positions are becoming more frequent with increased use of laparoscopic surgeries. The current technologies in assessing neuromuscular blockade are not functional in these types of surgical positions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Neuromuscular blockade is importantly used to paralyze muscles of patients undergoing surgery in order to allow for endotracheal intubation and prevent any spasmodic movement that could become catastrophic for a surgical procedure. In the current practice, the use of a peripheral nerve stimulator on the ulnar nerve of the arm causes thumb twitches, and anesthesiologists assess the thumb twitches qualitatively and in some cases quantitatively to understand the level of paralysis. 

In this project, we developed a muscle assesment device that can help anesthesiologists understand the level muscle paralysis in surgery. The device uses a train of four test that is commonly performed in the surgery room to have thumb twitches for visual assessment of muscle paralysis. In our device, a balloon is used to capture thumb twitches into pressure signals, which is used by anesthesiologist as a quantitative way of assessing muscle paralysis. We design the device such that it operates even in adverse surgical positions such as when the arms are tucked besides the body or when they are under cover. With this device, anesthesiologists would accurately know how much neuromuscular blockade to administer to each patient and when to reverse its effects. This avoids the risk of postoperative residual neuromuscular blockade, which refers to patients having neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) in their body even after surgery completion. By ensuring complete neuromuscular recovery, the device minimizes respiratory complications and unpleasant symptoms of muscle weakness caused by residual NMBAs in the body post-surgery. 

With the funding from NSF, we have completed the I-Corps training. In this training, we have performed 100+ interviews with medical professionals, such as anesthesiologists, anesthesia assistants, nurses, department heads, medical school professors, and hospital staff for purchasing. We have gained an understanding of the end users, the acquisition process in hospitals, and other details for forming a strong business model. A smaller portion of funding was used to advance the protoype. We designed and verified electronics of the prototype. Consequently, this project made us closer to commercialization of this new technology for the benefit of the society. 


Last Modified: 07/11/2023
Modified by: Ahmet C Sabuncu

Image
  • Quantitative Train of Four Monitoring Prototype
    Ahmet Can Sabuncu, Shu Guo, and Lee Moradi
    Copyrighted
    Ahmet C Sabuncu
